overall_summary: The reasoning trajectory demonstrates a thorough analysis of a short time-series dataset with clear daily seasonality. The analyst systematically evaluates multiple forecasting approaches (SARIMA, Exponential Smoothing, Fourier regression) but ultimately selects a simple averaging method due to data limitations. The reasoning highlights practical constraints of limited historical data (96 hourly points) and emphasizes robustness over complexity, while carefully considering patterns and potential weekly effects despite insufficient modeling capacity.
common_data_patterns: Potential weekly patterns (insufficient data for modeling)
Complete historical records (no missing values in provided data)
Day-of-week level variations (higher values on Thu/Sun vs Fri/Sat)
key_insights: Prioritizing simplicity when data is limited (4 days) to avoid overfitting complex models
Explicit handling of seasonality through averaging same-hour observations across days
Recognition of weekly patterns despite inability to model them with available data
Systematic evaluation of model trade-offs (SARIMA vs ETS vs Fourier vs averaging)
Hour-by-hour computation of seasonal averages as a robust baseline approach
complexity_analysis: Highly detailed multi-step analysis exploring advanced statistical models, but final implementation reverts to simple heuristics due to data constraints and practical considerations.
